reviewText:
Let's not dance around the point: this isn't a very good game.

However, it has the potential to be: it has quality art and decent sound. The only thing needing work is the writing, which is less than ideal for something that purports to be a visual novel.

The writing is rushed and rough, switching between scenes suddenly and quite often without an indication why. At times, it explains nothing, while other times, it dumps info on you. It's incoherent, and doesn't appear to have had a pass for formatting, presentation and grammar.

It looks like a first project, and that inspires both hope and anger in me. Hope, because I think the ideas presented and the storyline feebly attempted are worthwhile, and can be salvaged. Please, read some tutorials, practice more, and then revisit this - I really think it deserves it.

Anger, because the visuals are quality. It's above-average in places, good in most, and even great at times. As a writer-programmer without an artist, it's sad to see art like this so callously wasted by sub-par writing and bad UI.

At this stage, I cannot recommend it, apart from having a quick skim-through for the ideas presented. If, in future, the writing is improved, I will adjust my opinion - I certainly hope I will get that chance.

reviewText:
My first visual novel, I must say I liked it.
Story is nice, game is very short indeed, but since it's free is fine. Hopefully they will continue this story otherwise makes it a bit disappointing because it looks unfinished. I found it very interesting so I really want this to continue. The emotions and thoughts of the main character are nicely shown, it makes you feel her and pretty much like her from start.

I recommend this mostly If you like cyberpunk.
Art is great, even if you play this just for that, is worth it.
Music could have been better I'd like it to fit more the future style but as a general music for a novel is good and emotional.

Would look forward to see the story completed. Think of it as a prologue and you will be satisfied!

Positives

+ The story and world is very interesting.
+ The characters are likable and have personality.
+ The music is cool and fits the scenes.
+ For a free game, the characters and backgrounds are nicely drawn.
+ The game is free.
+ I don't remember seeing any typos.

Neutral

= The main menu takes getting used to, but the creators said that they are going to be fixing that in the future.
= There were one or two moments where the dialogue felt unnatural.

Negative

- The story and character development feels very rushed, as if this were a condensed version of a full visual novel.
- A whole bunch of information is thrown at you within such a short amount of time that it doesn't allow you to fully enjoy what is going on or get wrapped up in the characters and plot.

Final Verdict

5/10 - Because of how rushed it is, the game is average. But I do think that if they had not made it a free game and instead created a full visual novel, this would have been very cool, if not awesome. But don't take my word for it. Try it for yourself. It is free, after all.

This visual novel is a great learning experience for starting visual novel creators as it's not 'just' a rough gem', it's an extremely rough gem with very fundamental flaws.

The game runs on a custom engine made for iOS and poorly ported to windows, and it really shows. There is literally only one hotkey and that's the spacebar for 'next line'. Every other function is a button either on screen or in the menu (which is also a seperate button). On iOS this makes sense since tabbing the screen at any place other than a button can only have one function.

Another result of this is that many functions are cut. There are no options for sound management (which isn't that much of an issue since the only sound is background music, making your line-out the only sound management you actually need), different screen sizes, text speed, font size, skip options, or jiggle physics (which is sliiiightly less important than the other options missing). It's all cut down to the bare minimum of 'play, save and load'.

It COULD work, but it doesn't here. The background is usually very light, but they use non-bordered white letters for this visual novel. The black bar that the text was displayed on, was, in combination with what I mentioned last line, not enough to actually make it readable at the speed I desired to read it at. This could be fixed in either one of two ways:  give the translucid bar a higher opacity or an opacity slider in the options, or make the text borded by a small 2px black line.

Another thing, that's a clear relic of the iOS days, is that the buttons feel extremely unresponsive. This is, simply, because there is no feedback at all. I imagine that on iOS, the phone would vibrate a bit, and that visual aids aren't needed since you don't see the button anyway when your finger is in front of it, but on windows I can never tell whether or not I quicksaved.

The biggest flaw is the lack of history. In most visual novels, you can either press a button or scroll up to see some of the past dialogue, but in this game, that's not possible. Since it's a sci-fi game and not some romantic comedy, you sometimes really want this function when something in the next line refers to something you accidently read over in the previous line.


What to learn from it:
1. get, besides a load and save option, at least a way to customize some of the game, be it by resolution changes or some extra slider bars in an option menu
2. make sure that there's an option to read older dialogue
3. make buttons responsive/when you port an engine, optimise it well for the new platform.

Sprites suffer from a lack of transitions, the default, boring textbox makes it hard to read the text at times, and by the point I had to give up on this game, every major speaking character had the same color name, making it a chore to keep track of conversations. In a medium that focuses largely on dialogue, those are pretty huge mistakes.

Use of sound effects was sparse, while the music was generally lacking. The game opens with a public domain piece, and at one point there's a song that's literally five seconds long and badly looped over and over. Add to that what appears to be a complete lack of any kind of options screen or main menu, plus absolutely wooden writing that has about as much style and substance as a bowl of tapioca, and you have a recipe for... well, something that's just not any good.

I enjoyed this short visual novel a lot. The characters are interesting and likeable, though only the protagonist is fully fleshed out. The near future setting is well presented and believable, not overly dystopian as is sometimes the case. The story is good and intriguing, though short, as it continues in the sequel. The music is fantastic and does a lot to set the mood of the game. I think the art is beautiful.

This is not a novel where you steer the story by your choices. There is only a handful of choices, and some of them lead to the story ending early. (You should save occasionally). The choices are more about understanding what the protagonist could and would do in some scenarios. She is talented and capable but also vulnerable. She is not an action hero and has to prioritize self preservation in her choices. The choices are there to emphasize that aspect of the character, and they work well in that regard.

On the negative side, the dialogue writing is merely OK, but not bad enough to distract from the good parts. The characters except the protagonist are not fully developed and their motivations are not quite clear, hopefully this is expanded upon in the sequel. There is also a small number of typos, not nearly enough to affect the experience.

This novel can easily be finished in one sitting, in under an hour. It has good story, art and music. I heartily recommend it.
